    • Method Detail

      • open

        static CommunicationRegistration open()

      • register

        <T> ReceivePipeline<T> register(Class<T> type)
        Sets/maintains a ReceivePipeline to handle a given Object of the provided Class.

        Because of type-erasure, the type check has to be done at runtime. You will never get an receivePipeline of another type

        Type Parameters:
        T - the Type of the Object, identified by the provided Class
        Parameters:
        type - the Class of the Object, that should be handled.
        Returns:
        either a new or an already established instance of the ReceivePipeline

      • registered

        default <T> ReceivePipeline<T> registered(Class<T> type)
        Retrieves the already registered ReceivePipeline, for the provided type. If there is no ReceivePipeline registered, this method throws a IllegalArgumentException. The main use of this Method is within a scenario, where you require the ReceivePipeline to be registered beforehand, like if you want to update a ReceivePipeline programmatically at a certain point after the Application has been launched.
        Type Parameters:
        T - the Type of the Object, identified by the provided Class
        Parameters:
        type - the Class of the Object, that should be handled.
        Returns:
        either a new or an already established instance of the ReceivePipeline
        See Also:
        isRegistered(Class), register(Class)

      • ifRegistered

        default <T> void ifRegistered(Class<T> type,
                              java.util.function.Consumer<ReceivePipeline<T>> consumer)
        Retrieves the already registered ReceivePipeline, for the provided type.

        If there is no ReceivePipeline registered, this method throws a IllegalArgumentException.

        The main use of this Method is within a scenario, where you require the ReceivePipeline to be registered beforehand, like if you want to update a ReceivePipeline programmatically at a certain point after the Application has been launched.

        Type Parameters:
        T - the Type of the Object, identified by the provided Class
        Parameters:
        type - the Class of the Object, that should be handled.

      • unRegister

        void unRegister(Class type)
        Removes the internally set instance of the ReceivePipeline, handling an Object of the same Type as the provided clazz.

        This will ignore any ReceivePipelineHandlerPolicy set to the maintained ReceivePipeline. It will simply remove the set instance.

        Parameters:
        type - the Class, that defines the type of the ReceivePipeline

      • isRegistered

        boolean isRegistered(Class type)
        Determines whether or not a ReceivePipeline is registered to handle Objects of the same Type as clazz
        Parameters:
        type - the Class, that defines the type of the ReceivePipeline
        Returns:
        true if any ReceivePipeline is set, false otherwise

      • trigger

        @Asynchronous
 @Deprecated
default void trigger(Connection connection,
                                                Session session,
                                                Object object)
                                         throws CommunicationNotSpecifiedException
        Deprecated. 
        This method is used to trigger a ReceivePipeline, with the provided arguments.

        All it does, is to call trigger(Class, Connection, Session, Object), with the direct Class of the provided Object Since the ConnectionContext has been introduced to provide a couple between the Connection and the Client, this method is a potential candidate for deprecated.

        Parameters:
        connection - the Connection over which the Object was received
        session - the Session, identifying the other end of the Connection
        object - the Object that was received
        Throws:
        CommunicationNotSpecifiedException - if no ReceivePipeline is set for the provided class and no DefaultCommunicationHandler is set
        See Also:
        trigger(Class, Connection, Session, Object)

      • trigger

        @Asynchronous
 @Deprecated
default <T> void trigger(Class<T> type,
                                                    Connection connection,
                                                    Session session,
                                                    Object o)
                                             throws CommunicationNotSpecifiedException
        Deprecated. 
        This method takes a Object and runs it through a ReceivePipeline of the Type that is defined by the provided Class.

        This method provides the possibility to define other Class-Types than the Object is of. This is due to inheritance. If you want to run an Object through this CommunicationRegistration, but you want it to be handled by an ReceivePipeline, that only handles the super type or an declared/inherited interface, you may do that.

        By calling this Method, you are basically running the provided Object through the internally maintained ReceivePipeline. The other provided parameters (connection, session) will be needed regardless of the internally set handlers. This is because the ReceivePipeline does not know whether any set Handler needs those parameters or not. It only knows OnReceiveTriple

        To ensure scalability, this Method extracts the actual run of the ReceivePipeline into another Thread. Therefor this method does not rethrow thrown Errors, Exceptions and RuntimeExceptions, thrown by the ReceiveHandler.

        If no ReceivePipeline was ever registered to this CommunicationRegistration, it will throw an CommunicationNotSpecifiedException. his behaviour can be overridden by providing an DefaultCommunicationHandler with addDefaultCommunicationHandler(OnReceive) Since the ConnectionContext has been introduced to provide a couple between the Connection and the Client, this method is a potential candidate for deprecated.

        Type Parameters:
        T - the Type of the ReceivePipeline
        Parameters:
        type - the Class, defining the Type of the ReceivePipeline
        connection - the Connection, over which the Object has been received
        session - the Session, identifying the other end of the Connection
        o - the Object, that was received over the Connection
        Throws:
        CommunicationNotSpecifiedException - if no ReceivePipeline is set for the provided type and no DefaultCommunicationHandler has been set.
        See Also:
        OnReceiveTriple, Wrapper

      • trigger

        void trigger(ConnectionContext connectionContext,
             Session session,
             Object object)
      throws CommunicationNotSpecifiedException
        Throws:
        CommunicationNotSpecifiedException

      • trigger

        @Asynchronous
<T> void trigger(Class<T> type,
                               ConnectionContext connectionContext,
                               Session session,
                               Object o)
                        throws CommunicationNotSpecifiedException
        This method takes a Object and runs it through a ReceivePipeline of the Type that is defined by the provided Class.

        This method provides the possibility to define other Class-Types than the Object is of. This is due to inheritance. If you want to run an Object through this CommunicationRegistration, but you want it to be handled by an ReceivePipeline, that only handles the super type or an declared/inherited interface, you may do that.

        By calling this Method, you are basically running the provided Object through the internally maintained ReceivePipeline. The other provided parameters (connection, session) will be needed regardless of the internally set handlers. This is because the ReceivePipeline does not know whether any set Handler needs those parameters or not. It only knows OnReceiveTriple

        To ensure scalability, this Method extracts the actual run of the ReceivePipeline into another Thread. Therefor this method does not rethrow thrown Errors, Exceptions and RuntimeExceptions, thrown by the ReceiveHandler.

        If no ReceivePipeline was ever registered to this CommunicationRegistration, it will throw an CommunicationNotSpecifiedException. his behaviour can be overridden by providing an DefaultCommunicationHandler with addDefaultCommunicationHandler(OnReceive) Since the ConnectionContext has been introduced to provide a couple between the Connection and the Client, this method is a potential candidate for deprecated.

        Type Parameters:
        T - the Type of the ReceivePipeline
        Parameters:
        type - the Class, defining the Type of the ReceivePipeline
        connectionContext - the ConnectionContext, over which the Object has been received
        session - the Session, identifying the other end of the Connection
        o - the Object, that was received over the Connection
        Throws:
        CommunicationNotSpecifiedException - if no ReceivePipeline is set for the provided type and no DefaultCommunicationHandler has been set.
        See Also:
        OnReceiveTriple, Wrapper

      • addDefaultCommunicationHandler

        void addDefaultCommunicationHandler(OnReceiveSingle<Object> defaultCommunicationHandler)
        Sets an OnReceiveSingle as the default handling routine for any Object that is not registered specifically
        Parameters:
        defaultCommunicationHandler - the OnReceiveSingle that should be run, if no registration was found for a specific provided Object

      • addDefaultCommunicationHandler

        void addDefaultCommunicationHandler(OnReceive<Object> defaultCommunicationHandler)
        Sets an OnReceive as the default handling routine for any Object that is not registered specifically
        Parameters:
        defaultCommunicationHandler - the OnReceive that should be run, if no registration was found for a specific provided Object

      • addDefaultCommunicationHandler

        void addDefaultCommunicationHandler(OnReceiveTriple<Object> defaultCommunicationHandler)
        Sets an OnReceiveTriple as the default handling routine for any Object that is not registered specifically
        Parameters:
        defaultCommunicationHandler - the OnReceiveTriple that should be run, if no registration was found for a specific provided Object

      • clear

        void clear()
        Clears all set registration.

        This Call will ignore the set ReceivePipelineHandlerPolicy.

        All internally set ReceivePipeline will be cleared. Currently running Handlers will NOT be stopped.

      • clearAllEmptyPipelines

        void clearAllEmptyPipelines()
        This call wil unregister all ReceivePipeline if the ReceivePipeline.isEmpty() call returns true.

        The one exception for this rule is, if an ReceivePipeline is sealed. Any sealed ReceivePipeline will not be tested and therefor not removed, even if they are empty. This ensures that critical empty ReceivePipeline are not collected.

      • updateBy

        void updateBy(CommunicationRegistration communicationRegistration)
        This call will override any internally set registrations and set all registration to the provided CommunicationRegistration.

        This will ignore any ReceivePipelineHandlerPolicy and delete all Registrations currently set.

        This CommunicationRegistration will take all instances from the provided CommunicationRegistration! This means, both are now nearly identical! A change at one ReceivePipeline in any of those CommunicationRegistrations will lead to the same change in the other CommunicationRegistration!

        Parameters:
        communicationRegistration - the CommunicationRegistration, that will provide its Registration.

      • map

        Map<Class,ReceivePipeline<?>> map()
        Creates a Map that maps the internally maintained ReceivePipeline to the Class they have been Registered with.
        Returns:
        a map, pointing from the Class-Type to the ReceivePipeline that handles this Type or any subtype

      • listDefaultsCommunicationRegistration

        List<OnReceiveTriple<Object>> listDefaultsCommunicationRegistration()
        Lists all set DefaultCommunicationHandlers
        Returns:
        a List with all set DefaultCommunicationHandlers
        See Also:
        addDefaultCommunicationHandler(OnReceive), addDefaultCommunicationHandler(OnReceiveSingle), addDefaultCommunicationHandler(OnReceiveTriple)
